pages.text: Berthasaura leopoldinae comes from the Early Cretaceous, with fossils being found in the Goio-Erê Formation, Brazil. It is a small ceratosaur, growing to 1 m in length. It preserves the most complete axial series (backbone) of any noasaurid to date, and its short, toothless beak suggests that it was either at least a herbivore or at most an omnivore,

unlike most other ceratosaurs, which were carnivorous. The generic name derives from the name of Bertha Maria Júlia Lutz, a Brazilian Zoologist and women's right activist; and the Greek word 'sauros', to mean 'lizard'. The specific name derives from the surname of Maria Leopoldina, the first Empress of Brazil.
